AltNetConf UK London August 2009

Posted by Ian Cooper on May 15, 2009

It feels as though sufficient water has passed under-the-bridge for us to have another altnetconf in London. We tend to organize them when the ‘mood’ seems right in the community. That usually means that we think folks have something to discuss. This time we are planning on the weekend of 1 August (31 JUL to 2 AUG). Registration should open on 12 May. Don’t be alarmed if you see an old version of the site before then.

Numbers are still limited. The wider economy means that we are unlikely to get the sponsorship for a bigger venue this year. We’ll keep trying though.

That said Alan Dean, Ben Hall, and myself have been plotting in secret, and roped in Sebastian Lambla and Michelle Flynne to help so that we can hold a bigger event in terms of the amount we do. So this time the plan is:

31 JUL Evening: Alt.Net Beers: Yes we are integrating Seb’s alt.net event to warm you up with a chance to relax with like-minded individuals

1 AUG Day: Open Space Coding: Alan Dean’s Open Space Coding Day event joins our weekend. the emphasis is on writing code over jawing. 

2 AUG Day: AltNetConf: Open Space discussion about the topics that have grabbed you today. Be prepare to be surprised.

UPDATE: We had a request from attendees at Progressive .NET to delay registration, as they are a key attendance group. I’ll update with the new time, likely to be Thursday lunchtime or evening.

UPDATE: We have now opened registration: http://www.altnetuk.com/registration.en.html

 

I’m looking forward to this one. It feels as though it has been long enough that we ought to have some things to talk about, not just re-hashing the old saws.

About Ian Cooper

Ian Cooper has over 18 years of experience delivering Microsoft platform solutions in government, healthcare, and finance. During that time he has worked for the DTi, Reuters, Sungard, Misys and Beazley delivering everything from bespoke enterpise solutions to 'shrink-wrapped' products to thousands of customers. Ian is a passionate exponent of the benefits of OO and Agile. He is test-infected and contagious. When he is not writing C# code he is also the and founder of the London .NET user group. http://www.dnug.org.uk
